I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  for  the  Hai  River  Estuary  Area  Pollution  Control  and 
Ecosystem  Rehabilitation  Project.  The  report  also  describes  the  technical  assistance  (TA)  for 
Capacity Development for Green Growth Demonstration, and if the Board approves the loan, I, 
acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA.1 

The  project  will  support  the  Tianjin  municipal  government  (TMG)  to  implement  green 
2. 
growth  demonstration  activities  in  the  coastal  areas  south  of  the  Hai  River  estuary  that  will 
contribute  to  a  recycling  economy.  The  project  proposed  for  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB) 
financing includes (i) wastewater management and pollution control, including the establishment 
of a wastewater treatment plant (WWTP) and water reuse facilities along the south bank of the 
Hai  River  estuary;  (ii)  clean-up  and  reuse  of  contaminated  sediment  in  the  Hai  River  estuary 
area;  (iii)  ecosystem  rehabilitation  in  the  Hai  River  estuary  area;  (iv)  establishment  of  an 
environmental  monitoring  and  emergency  response  center  (EMERC)  in  the  Harbor  Economic 
Area  (HEA),  formerly  called  the  Harbor  Industrial  Park;  and  (v)  prevention  of  storm-surge 
disasters.2  

A. 

Rationale 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

3. 
Tianjin  municipality,  the  sixth  largest  city  and  one  of  four  special  municipalities  in  the 
PRC  with  a  provincial  status,  has  a  total  area  of  11,760  square  kilometers  (km2)  and  a 
population  of  11.6  million.  It  is  located  in  the  lowest  reach  of  the  Hai  River  basin.  Of  the  nine 
major rivers in the basin, seven flow through Tianjin to the Bohai Sea.3 The central government 
identifies the Tianjin Binhai New Area (TBNA), established in January 2010 and administered by 
Tianjin municipality, as the third economic growth focal point of the country, after Shenzhen in 
the 1980s and the Shanghai Pudong area in the 1990s. With a planned area of 2,270 km2 and 
population of 1.4 million, this new development area is proposed to become a center of finance, 
business, and industry in the northern PRC in the near future. TBNA contributed more than 50% 
of TMG’s gross domestic product in 2009.  

4. 
The HEA, a land reclamation area in the tidal-flat portion of Bohai Bay, south of the Hai 
River  estuary,  is  one  of  the  functional  areas  in  TBNA.  The  development  of  this  state 
demonstration  zone  for  the  recycling  economy  began  in  2003  and  is  due  to  be  completed  by 
2018.  The  area  will  accommodate  large  domestic  and  international  companies,  including 
petrochemical 
industries,  shipyards,  offshore  oil  engineering  bases,  heavy  equipment 
manufacturing,  technological  research,  and  development  institutes;  and  will  provide  for 
residential areas and corresponding public utilities. It will also accommodate industries that will 
be  moved  from  existing  residential  areas.  The  initial  2005  master  plan  for  HEA  development 
covered three phases, with a total area of about 80 km2. Land reclamation under phase I (about 
20 km2) is complete; industries are still being established. Phase I includes the ADB-supported 
integrated gasification combined-cycle power plant, which is more efficient than other clean coal 
technologies and emits less greenhouse gases and only a fraction of sulfur dioxide and nitrogen 

                                                
1   The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
2   ADB  provided  project  preparatory  TA.  ADB.  2009.  Technical  Assistance  to  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  for 
Preparing  the  Hai  River  Pollution  Control  and  Ecosystem  Rehabilitation.  Manila  (TA  7312-PRC,  $700,000, 
approved on 14 July).  

3   The Bohai Sea, also known as the Bohai Gulf, is the innermost gulf of the Yellow Sea on the northeastern coast of 

the PRC. Bohai Bay is one of three bays forming the Bohai Sea. 

 2 

 

oxide pollutants.4 Land reclamation under phases II and III is ongoing; about 30 km2 of the total 
60  km2 are  completed.  In  2010, the Tianjin Harbor  Economic Area  Administrative  Commission 
(HEAAC) approved the revised master plan, which (i) restructures the plan for phases II and III 
areas to accommodate cleaner, nonpolluting industries; and (ii) extends the HEA to 200 km2 to 
encompass the adjacent Harbor Manufacturing Park. Future impacts of climate change on  the 
HEA are of concern for TMG, which is taking measures to ensure adequate resilience.  

5. 
Rapid economic development in the Hai River basin and the Bohai Bay coastal areas of 
Tianjin  municipality  has  resulted  in  the  degradation  and  scarcity  of  natural  and  environmental 
resources.  Impacts  include  (i)  highly  polluted  waterways  because  of  untreated  wastewater 
discharges;  (ii)  silted  canals  with  highly  contaminated  sediments,  including  heavy  metals  and 
persistent  organic  pollutants;  and  (iii)  serious  degradation  of  the  Bohai  Sea  ecosystems.  The 
government  has  been  addressing  the  serious  water  pollution  problems  in  the  Hai  River  basin 
and  Bohai  Bay  by  (i)  promoting  an  integrated  approach  to  water  management  in  river  basins 
and coastal development zones; (ii) reducing pollution sources, particularly industrial and urban 
point  sources;  and  (iii)  continuing  institutional  and  financial  management  reforms  to  facilitate 
sustainable  environmental  management.  Many  development  partners,  including  ADB,  the 
Global  Environment  Facility, 
international 
nongovernment organizations, provide assistance to help control pollution in the Hai River basin. 
These efforts have primarily focused on controlling upstream pollution sources and constructing 
WWTPs,  which  have  resulted  in  significant  improvements  for  the  urban  areas  in  Tianjin 
municipality. 5  To  reduce  upstream  pollution,  TMG  recently  developed  a  3-year  action  plan 
(2010–2012), which aims to (i) reduce sewage overflow to rivers in urban areas; and (ii) improve 
the  wastewater  collection  and  treatment  ratio  from  82%  in  2008  to  90%  by  2012.  The  action 
plan  sets  a  target  of 30% for  the  water  reuse  ratio.  Both  are  significantly  higher than for  other 
cities  in  the  PRC.  The  Bohai  Gulf  also  suffers  from  frequent  and  serious  storm  surges  year-
round. Storm surges have caused serious damage to Tianjin and increase the risks of pollution 
accidents. 

the  World  Bank,  and 

the  United  Nations, 

6. 
Implementation of related ADB-financed projects demonstrates that the introduction and 
strengthening  of green growth approaches  are  critical for  sustainable development  of Tianjin’s 
coastal  areas. 6  Rapid  economic  development  often  overshadows  the  need  to  integrate 
adequate environmental management practices and risk mitigation measures into development 
activities.  The  project  integrates  the  lessons  and  complements  achievements  under  related 
ADB-financed  projects,  including  the  Tianjin  Wastewater  Treatment  and  Water  Resources 
Protection Project, the Hebei Province Wastewater Management Project, and the Shandong Hai 
River Basin Pollution Control Project; and the World Bank-financed Hai Basin Integrated Water 
and  Environment  Management  Project.7 Lessons  include  (i)  the  need  to  promote  innovative 
technology  and  standards  for  project  components,  including  sound  solutions  for  sludge 
treatment; (ii) the importance of providing realistic projections for wastewater flows; and (iii) the 
                                                
4   ADB. 2010. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan and Grant to 
the People’s Republic of China for the Tianjin Integrated Gasification Combined Cycle Power Plant Project. Manila. 
5   Governments and enterprises in the region built 78 sewage treatment plants with the capacity to treat 4.668 million 

tons of sewage per day. 

6   Sector Assessment (Summary): Agriculture and Natural Resources (accessible from the list of linked documents in 

Appendix 2); ADB. 2008. Country Partnership Strategy: People’s Republic of China, 2008–2010. Manila. 

7  ADB.  2000.  Report  and  Recommendation  of  the  President  to  the  Board  of  Directors:  Proposed  Loan  to  the 
People’s Republic of China for the Tianjin Wastewater Treatment and Water Resources Protection Project. Manila; 
ADB.  2002.  Report  and  Recommendation  of  the  President  to  the  Board  of  Directors:  Proposed  Loan  to  the 
People’s Republic of China for the  Hebei Province Wastewater Management Project. Manila; ADB. 2006.  Report 
and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan to the People’s Republic of China 
for the Shandong Hai River Basin Pollution Control Project.  Manila;  and World Bank. 2004. Hai Basin Integrated 
Water  and  Environment  Management  Project.  http://web.worldbank.org/external/projects/main?menuPK= 
228424&theSitePK=40941&pagePK=64283627&piPK=73230&Projectid=P075035 (accessed on 4 February 2011).  

 need to address financial and institutional arrangements for proper operation and maintenance 
(O&M). Activities are needed to (i) demonstrate practical green growth interventions that can be 
easily  replicated;  and  (ii)  strengthen  sound  environmental  management  for  the  rapidly 
developing  TBNA  functional  areas,  which  poses  significant  challenges  for  local  governments. 
Specific concerns include government capacity to (i) provide and protect scarce environmental 
resources,  such  as freshwater  ecosystems;  (ii)  control  existing  and  potential  pollution  sources 
and avoid accidents; (iii) establish adequate emergency and disaster risk management; and (iv) 
adapt  to  potential  climate  change  impacts  and  sea-level  rise.  Climate  change  impacts  have 
already resulted in an increase in the incidence of storm surges, subsequent economic damage, 
and increased exposure to environmental accidents and disasters. 

7. 
The project supports ADB’s strategic priorities in the country partnership strategy (2008–
2010)  and the  country  operations  business  plan  (2011–2013)  for  the  PRC.  It  aims  to  promote 
inclusive growth and environmental sustainability.8 The project has a strong linkage with ADB’s 
emerging  water  operational  plan,  which  focuses  on  wastewater  management  and  reuse, 
pollution  control,  and  river  rehabilitation.  It  also  supports  the  PRC’s  sustainable  development 
agenda  for  a  harmonious  society,  as  outlined  in  the  PRC’s  Twelfth  Five-Year  Plan  (2011–
2015). 9  Climate  change  and  environmental  sustainability  are  key  considerations,  including 
greater  preparedness  for  extreme  weather  events,  reduction  of  heavy  metal  and  wastewater 
pollution, and conservation of water and natural resources.  

B. 

Impact and Outcome 

8. 
The impact of the project will be sustained green growth in the Bohai Bay coastal areas 
of  Tianjin  municipality.  The  outcome  will  be  innovative  environmental  and  public  safety 
investments demonstrated in the HEA.  

C. 

Outputs 

The  project comprises  three  outputs  in  the  HEA: (i)  water  conservation and ecosystem 
9. 
rehabilitation  implemented,  (ii)  disaster  prevention  and  emergency  response  management 
established,  and  (iii)  capacity  development  and  project  implementation  support  provided.  The 
outputs will demonstrate innovative and sustainable environmental investment activities that can 
be replicated and applied in similar coastal development areas in the PRC.  

10.  Water  conservation  and  ecosystem  rehabilitation.  This  output  has 
three 
subcomponents:  (i)  wastewater  collection,  treatment,  and  reuse  to  support  TBNA’s  water 
conservation  target;  (ii)  development  of  a  constructed  wetland  for  secondary  treatment  and 
reuse of predominantly industrial wastewater; and (iii) management of contaminated sediments. 
The  wastewater  collection,  treatment,  and  reuse  subcomponent  includes  the  construction  of  a 
30,000-cubic  meter  per  day  (m3/day)  WWTP  and  about  80  kilometers  of  sanitary  sewers  on 
phases  II  and  III  land  available  for  construction  by  2017.  Domestic  sewage  and  industrial 
wastewater discharges of a similar nature will be collected and treated by the newly constructed 
WWTP.10 Sludge  will  be  reused  by  abstracting  of  protein  pellets  and  composting.  The  first 
subcomponent includes building a reverse osmosis plant that treats WWTP effluent and reuses 
water  for  industrial  applications.  The  capacity  of  the  reverse  osmosis  treatment  will  be  15,000 
m3/day, which will generate 10,000 m3/day of reclaimed water to be used for cooling water in the 

                                                
8   ADB.  2008.  Country  Partnership  Strategy:  People’s  Republic  of  China,  2008–2010.  Manila;  and  ADB.  2011. 

Country Operations Business Plan: People’s Republic of China, 2011–2013. Manila. 

9  Government of the People’s Republic of China, National People’s Congress. 2011. Outline of the Twelfth Five-Year 

Plan of the People’s Republic of China, 2011–2015. Beijing. 

10  More  polluted  industrial  wastewaters  are  separately  collected  and  treated  by  SembCorp,  an  industrial  WWTP 

operating in the phase I area. 

3 

 

 4 

 

 

integrated  gasification  combined-cycle  power  plant.  For  the  second  subcomponent,  a 
constructed  wetland  will  be  built  on  about  60  hectares  with  recreational  functions.  The 
constructed wetland will be fed with class ―IB‖ WWTP effluents and produce class ―IA‖ effluent 
for  the  replenishment  of  water  bodies  in  the  HEA.11 The  third  subcomponent,  management  of 
contaminated  sediments,  includes  dredging  and  treating  of  about  1.8  million  m3  of  sediment 
from the lower section of the Dagu canal the Hai River estuary area, and associated civil works 
and landscaping for Dagu canal bank improvement. 

Disaster  prevention  and  emergency  response  management.  This  output  has  two 
11. 
subcomponents: (i) storm-surge disaster reduction, and (ii) EMERC. The first subcomponent will 
construct  a  storm-surge  disaster  prevention  wall  (breakwater)  to  minimize  potential  risks  and 
damage caused by storm surges, and provide safe and efficient working conditions for the HEA 
harbor  area.  The  prevention  wall  is  about  3  kilometers  long  with  a  once-in-50-year  design 
standard.  The  second  subcomponent  will  establish  an  EMERC  to  target  pollutants  and 
emergencies  arising  in  the  HEA.  The  EMERC  civil  works  will  be  designed  to  serve  the  entire 
200  km2  HEA,  and  equipment  and  facilities  installed  for  the  EMERC  during  project 
implementation will serve the industries established in the 80 km2

 HEA. 

12. 
Capacity  development  and  project  implementation  support.  The  output  has  two 
subcomponents:  (i)  institutional  strengthening,  and  (ii)  project  management  support  to  be 
provided during project implementation. The main activities include design review, construction 
management,  procurement  management,  quality  management,  information  management, 
sustainable  O&M  arrangement,  project  monitoring  and  reporting,  and  training.  National  and 
international consultants will be recruited to undertake these assignments. 

D. 

Investment and Financing Plans 

13. 
The project is estimated to cost $249.12 million, including contingencies ($26.53 million), 
financing charges ($22.21 million), and taxes and duties ($11.6 million). The investment plan is 
summarized  in Table  1.  The  detailed  cost  estimates  by  expenditure  category  and  by  financier 
are included in the project administration manual (PAM).12 

The  government  has  requested  a  loan  of  $100  million  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital 
14. 
resources  to  help finance the  project. The  PRC  will  be  the  borrower. The loan will  have a 25-
year term, including a grace period of 5 years; an annual interest rate determined in accordance 
with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; a commitment charge 
of  0.15%  per  year;  interest  and  other  charges  during  construction,  as  applicable,  to  be 
capitalized  in  the  loan;  and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  as  set  forth  in  the  draft  loan  and 
project  agreements. The government  has  provided  ADB  with (i) the  reasons for  its  decision to 
borrow under ADB’s LIBOR-based lending facility based on these terms and conditions, and (ii) 
an undertaking that these choices were its own independent decision and not made in reliance 
on  any  communication  or  advice  from  ADB.  The  government  will  make  the  loan  proceeds 
available to TMG. TMG, through HEAAC, will make the loan proceeds, as specified in the PAM, 
available to the Harbor Industrial Park Construction and Development Company (HIPCDC) and 
the  Tianjin  Lingang  Port  Group  Company  (TLPGC)  upon  terms  and  conditions  as  specified  in 
the loan and project agreements. 

                                                
11  Class IA water quality is the current requirement for the disposal of treated wastewater.

Source: ADB estimates. 

15. 
The  financing  plan  is  in  Table  2.  ADB  will  finance  40.14%  of  the  total  project  costs, 
including  41%  of  the  costs  of  eligible  civil  works;  100%  of  the  cost  of  eligible  equipment  and 
training, and 30% of consulting services, excluding taxes and duties imposed within the territory 
of the borrower; and 100% of interest and commitment charges on the ADB loan.  Counterpart 
funds will come from self-financing by HIPCDC and TLPGC, central government bonds, and two 
commercial bank loans to be secured by HIPCDC and TLPGC. Of the total counterpart funds of 
$149.12  million,  about  $1.49  million  will  come  from  central  government  bonds,  about  $88.20 
million from two commercial bank loans, and the remaining $59.43 million directly from HIPCDC 
and TLPGC. The central government bonds will be used exclusively for financing part of the civil 
works cost for the constructed wetland. HIPCDC and TLPGC will draw down on the commercial 
bank loans as required to ensure timely release of sufficient counterpart financing.

E. 

Implementation Arrangements 

16. 
TBNA  will  undertake  oversight  responsibilities  and  ensure  coordination  among  TMG 
agencies,  such  as  the  Tianjin  environmental  protection,  finance,  oceanic,  and  water  resource 
bureaus;  and  the  Tianjin  provincial  development  and  reform  commission.  HEAAC  will  be  the 
executing agency. A project management office, established at HEAAC, will be responsible for 
overall  project  planning,  coordination,  and  supervision.  The  project  management  office  will 
initially  have  four  permanent  full-time  staff;  this  is  considered  adequate,  as  the  project  has 
engaged  a  procurement  agency  to  handle  project  procurement.  Staffing  will  be  assessed  and 
increased  based  on  project  implementation  needs  and  in  consultation  with  the  project 
consultants.  HIPCDC  and  TLPGC,  state-owned  corporations  operating  under  HEAAC,  will  be 
the  implementing  agencies.  Project  implementation  offices  have  been  established  in  HIPCDC 
and TLPGC. HIPCDC and TLPGC have established project implementation units with qualified 
staff for all subcomponents. The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 3 and 
described in detail in the PAM (footnote 12).

HEAAC has requested advance contracting and retroactive financing for 
contract packages covering consulting services and civil works for constructed 
wetland and wetland water treatment. Retroactive financing can only be applied 
up to a maximum of $20 million, or 20% of the total ADB loan amount, with 
respect to expenditures incurred before loan effectiveness, but not more than 
12 months before the signing of the loan agreement. 
The loan proceeds will be disbursed in accordance with ADB’s Loan

Consulting services

ADB = Asian Development Bank, HEAAC = Harbor Economic Area Administrative Commission. 
Source: ADB. 

The  project  comprises  innovative  outputs  requiring  technical  oversight  that  is  not 
17. 
available domestically. International best practices are to be applied for the sediment dredging, 
disposal  and  management  of  sludge  from  the  WWTP,  and  disaster  emergency  procedures  in 
the  estuary  area.  Approximately  31  person-months  of  international  consulting  and  45  person-

 months  of  national  consulting  services  will  be  required  under  the  loan  project.  HEAAC  will 
engage a consulting firm with international experience using quality-based selection to provide 
services  in  the  areas  of  design  review  and  application  of  international  best  management 
practices. 

III. 

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 

18. 
Technical assistance (TA) will strengthen the capacity of HEAAC, HIPCDC, and TLPGC 
for  applying  international  best  practices  in  environmental  management  and  establishing  the 
International  Organization  for  Standardization  (ISO)  quality  management  system  (ISO  9000) 
and  environmental  management  system  (ISO  14001).  The  TA  estimated  at  an  amount  not 
exceeding  $1  million  equivalent  will  be  provided  by  ADB  on  a  grant  basis  from  its  Technical 
Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The government will provide in-kind counterpart 
costs and services, including the remuneration and per diem of counterpart staff, miscellaneous 
administrative support, office accommodation, and local transport. The TA will be implemented 
over 3 years from 1 March 2012 to 28 February 2015. The proceeds of the TA will be disbursed 
in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook  (2010,  as  amended 
from  time  to  time).  ADB  will  engage  a  consulting  firm,  using  quality-based  selection  in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time), to provide 27 person-months of international and 25 person-months of national consulting 
services and training in the areas of quality and environmental management, and international 
best management practices. The TA is described in detail in the PAM (footnote 12).13 

A. 

Technical 

IV. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

19. 
Due diligence was conducted to assess the technical feasibility and sustainability of the 
project.  The  HEAAC-appointed  utility  company  will  undertake  the  WWTP  operation,  engaging 
professional  operators  for  technical  support  and  assurance. 14 HEACC  also  assures  that  the 
WWTP will be expanded after project completion in line with the wastewater generation to fully 
utilize the sewers built for  the phases II and III constructed area  by 2015. Treated wastewater 
will  be  reused  as  cooling  water;  a  purchase  agreement  has  been  reached  with  the  integrated 
gasification combined-cycle plant. International consulting services will include technical support 
to  ensure  enforcement  of  health  and  safety  measures;  and  training  for  sediment  dredging, 
dewatering,  transportation,  and  final  disposal,  following  international  best  practices.  HEAAC 
also assures that potential impacts from climate change (sea-level rise and increased incidence 
of storm surges) will be included in the final design.  

B. 

Economic and Financial 

20. 
The financial analysis demonstrates that HIPCDC and TLPGC, the final borrowers of the 
loan,  will  be  able to generate sufficient revenue  to repay  the  loan;  and that  in case  of  default, 
repayment  will  be  made  either  by  TMG  or  TBNA,  taking  into  account  their  existing  and future 
financial  capacities.  The  analysis  also  affirms  that  the  wastewater  subcomponent,  the  only 
revenue-generating  subcomponent  of  the  project,  is  financially  feasible  and  would  remain  so 
even in possible adverse scenarios. The economic analysis conducted for the subcomponents 
shows  that  they  are  all  economically  viable—the  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  is 

                                                
13 Technical Assistance (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).   
14  HEAAC  is  also  exploring  private  sector  participation  for  the  WWTP  operation  and  is  engaging  the  services  of 
operators  through  a  public  bidding  process  to  select  the  most  competent  contractor.  The  operators  of  the  two 
industrial WWTPs have already expressed interest in operating the plant. 

7 

 

 8 

 

12.7%  for  the  wastewater  subcomponent,  14.2%  for  the  constructed  wetland  subcomponent, 
and 18.1% for the storm-surge disaster prevention subcomponent. The EMERC subcomponent 
is envisaged to generate substantial unquantifiable economic benefits, such as reduced risk of 
environmental  pollution  and  safety  hazards.  The  contaminated  sediment 
treatment 
subcomponent was included in the economic analysis of the whole project, although the EIRR 
of  the  subcomponent  was  not  shown  separately  due  to  the  unquantifiable  economic  benefits, 
such  as  health  benefits.  The  economic  analysis  confirms  that  the  project  as  a  whole  is 
economically viable; this will not change even with a benefit decline or a capital cost increase of 
more than 5.5%. The EIRR for the entire project is 13.4%.15 

C. 

Governance 

The financial management assessment shows that HEAAC, HIPCDC, TLPGC, and the 
21. 
TMG  finance  bureau  will  be  able  to  perform  accounting  and  financial  reporting  to  satisfy  the 
needs for project implementation. The offices of the finance inspector, the key project inspector, 
and  the  discipline  supervisor  within  these  organizations  perform  part  of  the  internal  auditor’s 
function,  which  forms  the  internal  control  system.  The  procurement  capacity  assessment 
indicates that (i) TMG  has  successfully  implemented  several  projects financed  by  international 
development institutions; (ii) TBNA established arrangements for handling the various stages of 
procurement, including preparation of bid documents, tender invitation, bid evaluation, contract 
award, construction supervision, and contract performance monitoring in HEAAC, HIPCDC, and 
TLPGC;  and  (iii)  HIPCDC  and  TLPGC  engaged  a  professional  procurement  agency 
experienced  in  managing  procurement  processes  financed  by  international  development 
institutions.  However,  as  HEAAC,  HIPCDC,  and  TLPGC  have  not  yet  managed  any  ADB-
financed projects and are unfamiliar with ADB policies, guidelines, and procedural requirements, 
ADB  will  provide  assistance  and  training  to  HEAAC,  HIPCDC,  and  TLPGC  in  project 
management to achieve successful project implementation. 

ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
22. 
with  TMG,  including  HEAAC,  HIPCDC,  and  TLPGC.  The  relevant  sections  of  ADB’s 
Anticorruption Policy will be included in all documents and contracts relating to procurement and 
engagement of consultants. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures are 
described in the PAM (footnote 12). 

D. 

Poverty and Social 

The  project  will  serve  an  estimated  125,000  future  residents  of  the  HEA  by  providing 
23. 
safe water and greening of the residential area, such as a constructed wetland. The project will 
also serve an estimated existing population of 300,000–400,000 in the Tanggu District through 
improved  environmental  services.  An  estimated 150,000–200,000 jobs  will  be  created  through 
the  establishment  of  the  HEA,  and  additional  job  opportunities  will  be  created  during  project 
implementation.  By  contributing  to  the  clean  development  of  the  harbor  industrial  area,  the 
project will contribute to the creation of long-term development and labor perspectives for many 
years. The project will promote inclusive and gender-sensitive activities during implementation, 
and inclusiveness and gender-sensitivity of the future development of the harbor industrial zone, 
and the residential area included in it. During project implementation, project activities such as 
construction and O&M will be guided by the HEA policy that states that about 50% of skilled and 
managerial positions and 40% of unskilled positions should be provided to women, and 70% of 
unskilled  positions  to  local  poor  and  rural  migrant  workers.  Job  opportunities  will  be  provided 
respecting core labor standards, and implementing agencies and contractors will be required to 

                                                
15 Economic and Financial Analysis (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).   

 respect  national  regulations.  Job  opportunities  will  be  available  for  women  during  project 
implementation as well as in O&M during operations. The influx of construction workers to the 
port  area  and  neighboring  communities  demands  increasing  awareness  of  workers  and  the 
public  of  HIV/AIDS  and  sexually  transmitted  disease  risks.  Provisions  on  public  and  worker 
safety  and  health  are  included  in  the  environmental  management  plan  (EMP),  as  well  as 
schedules for consultation and participation procedures. 

E. 

Safeguards 

24. 
Environmental  assessment. The project classification for the environment is  category 
A.  An  environmental  impact  assessment  (EIA)  report  and  an  EMP  were  prepared  following 
ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009).  The  EIA  is  consistent  with  the  domestic 
environmental  assessment  reports  approved  in  November  2010  by  the  Tianjin  environmental 
protection and oceanic bureaus. Adequate consultations were conducted with affected persons 
and relevant stakeholders, and the EIA and EMP reports have been disclosed on ADB’s website 
since  August  2010.  The  EMP  includes  the  establishment  of  a  grievance  redress  mechanism, 
which has been discussed and agreed with the TBNA government. TBNA, through HEAAC, will 
be  responsible  for  overall  implementation  and  compliance  with  the  EMP  and  monitoring  plan, 
including inspection, monitoring, reporting, and initiating corrective actions or measures. HEAAC 
will have final responsibility for implementation of a grievance redress mechanism for handling 
any  disputes.  The  institutional  capacity  of  HEAAC  to  implement  the  EMP  and  ensure 
compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  is  considered  adequate.  The  project  is 
expected  to  achieve  significant  environmental  benefits,  including  (i)  reduced  overall  water 
demand  for  the  HEA;  (ii)  control  of  pollutants  discharged  into  the  Hai  River  estuary  area;  
(iii)  improved  water  quality  and  wetland  biodiversity;  (iv)  improved  water  quality  of  the  Dagu 
canal, and healthy and safe conditions for residents of the Hai River estuary area; (v) enhanced 
emergency preparedness and response capacity for pollution control and monitoring of the HEA 
and Hai River estuary; and (vi) a safer working environment for HEA workers.  

25. 
The  main  possible  adverse  environmental  impacts  and  risks  include  (i)  standard 
construction impacts, (ii) disposal of sludge from the WWTP, (iii) handling and management of 
polluted  sediments,  and  (iv)  potential  eutrophication  of  the  constructed  wetland  during 
operation. All impacts are expected to be prevented or minimized to an acceptable level through 
effective implementation  of  the  EMP  and monitoring  program.  HEAAC  and  the TA  consultants 
investigated  and  confirmed  that  the  contractor  engaged  for  receiving  the  WWTP  dewatered 
sludge  has  provided  a  viable  solution.  The  sludge  will  be  composted  for  land  application  after 
abstracting  protein  pellets.  The  technology  has  been  reviewed  and  confirmed  by  the  expert 
panel organized by the Tianjin government agency. The contaminated sediments will be treated 
and  reused  following  international  best  practices.  International  consulting  services  will  provide 
supervision  and  training  for  sediment  dredging,  dewatering,  transportation,  and  final  disposal; 
and  ensure  the  enforcement  of  health  and  safety  measures.  The  risk  of  eutrophication  is 
mitigated  through  the  application  of  adequate  engineering  measures  and  hydraulic  residence 
times,  and  the  implementation  of  a  comprehensive  water  quality  monitoring  program  of  the 
inflow water, as detailed in the EIA and EMP reports.  

26. 
Indigenous  peoples  and  involuntary  resettlement.  The  project  classification  for 
indigenous  peoples  and  involuntary  resettlement  is  category  C,  in  line  with  ADB’s  Safeguard 
Policy  Statement.  No  land  acquisition  or  involuntary  resettlement  will  be  required.  The  social 
safeguard aspects of the project are covered by a due diligence exercise, which demonstrates 
that no issues or impacts remain regarding involuntary resettlement. A sea area use certificate 
was obtained in 2005, and compensation to the former users of the sea area for the HEA was 
completed in 2007. A compensation review report was prepared that (i) describes the process 

9 

 

 10 

and  outcomes  of  the  compensation  process;  and  (ii)  assures  that  no  issues  remain,  and  no 
complaints were registered. Being located on newly reclaimed land, no indigenous peoples are 
affected by the project.  

F. 

Risks and Mitigating Measures 

27.  Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 4 and described in detail 
in  the  risk  assessment  and  risk  management  plan.16 The  integrated  benefits  and  impacts  are 
expected to outweigh the costs. 

Risks 

Mitigating Measures 

Table 4: Summary of Risks and Mitigating Measures

design

international technical assistance

pollution control failures

ensure adequate coordination and supervision of

ADB = Asian Development Bank, HEAAC = Harbor Economic Area Administrative Commission,  HIPCDC = Harbor 
Industrial Park Construction and Development Company, TBNA = Tianjin Binhai New Area, TLPGC = Tianjin Lingang 
Port Group Company, TMG = Tianjin municipal government. 
Source: ADB. 

V. 

ASSURANCES 

28. 
The government has assured ADB that implementation of the project will conform to all 
applicable  ADB  policies,  including  those  concerning  anticorruption  measures,  safeguards, 
gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail in the PAM 
(footnote 12) and loan documents. The government has agreed with ADB on certain covenants 
for the project, which are set forth in the loan and project agreements.  

VI. 

RECOMMENDATION 

29. 
I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and,  acting  in  the  absence  of  the  President,  under  the 
provisions  of  Article  35.1  of  the  Articles  of  Agreement  of  ADB,  I  recommend  that  the  Board 
approve the loan of $100,000,000 to the People’s Republic of China for the Hai River Estuary 
Area  Pollution  Control  and  Ecosystem  Rehabilitation  Project  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital 
resources,  with  interest  to  be  determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  London  interbank  offered 
rate-based lending facility; for a term of 25 years, including a grace period of 5 years; and such 
other  terms  and  conditions  as  are  substantially  in  accordance  with  those  set  forth  in  the  loan 
and project agreements presented to the Board. 

22 November 2011
